    33                                  ; Note:	This code is a part of Retro DOS 4.0 kernel source code
    34                                  ;	(as included binary, 'MSDOS5.BIN') 
    35                                  ;	Equivalent of MSDOS 5.0 MSDOS.SYS kernel file 
    36                                  ;	
    37                                  ;	((MSDOS 6.0 kernel source code has been modified by using disassembled
    38                                  ;	MSDOS 5.0 MSDOS.SYS)) -- Disassembler: HEX-RAYS IDA Pro --
    39                                  ;	((Disassembly -Reverse engineering- reference: MSDOS 6.0 kernel src))
    40                                        
    41                                  ;------ Retro DOS v2 (v3) boot sector loads RETRODOS.SYS (MSDOS.SYS)
    42                                  ;	at 1000h:0000h and loader (initialization) part of RETRODOS kernel
    43                                  ;	moves IO.SYS (DOSBIOSCODE & DOSBIOSDATA, 'IOSYS5.BIN') to 70h:0000h.
    44                                  ;	Then SYSINIT code to the next segment (4D6h for current version)..
    45                                  ;	SYSINIT code relocates itself and DOSBIOSCODE and MSDOS.SYS
    46                                  ;	(MSDOS5.BIN) according to request/setting in 'config.sys' file.
    47                                  
    48                                  ; ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
    49                                  
    50                                  ; 01/01/2024 - Retro DOS v5.0 Kernel ('ibmdos7.s')
    51                                  ; Modified from 'msdos6.s' (29/09/2023, Retro DOS v4.2 kernel: MSDOS.SYS) file
    52                                  ; as below:
    53                                  ;
    54                                  ;    1) Retro DOS v4.2 MSDOS.SYS is based on disassembled source code
    55                                  ;	of MSDOS 6.21 MSDOS.SYS, derived using MSDOS 6.0 source code.
    56                                  ;	(And then it has been verified and updated by comparing it with
    57                                  ;	the disassembled source code of MSDOS 6.22 kernel file MSDOS.SYS.)
    58                                  ;
    59                                  ;    2) Labels, names, comments, explanations and structure definitions
    60                                  ;	about procedures and code details are almost entirely taken from
    61                                  ;	the original MSDOS 6.0 source code, except for the details that
    62                                  ;	Erdogan Tan personally experienced. Some of them are incompatible
    63                                  ;	with PCDOS 7.1 code. But they have not been deleted to preserve
    64                                  ;	the originality of the descriptions.)
    65                                  ;
    66                                  ; ('msdos6.s' has been converted to 'ibmdos7.s' and 'retrodos42.s' has been
    67                                  ; converted to 'retrodos5.s'. 'ibmdos7.s' is IBMDOS.COM source code file
    68                                  ; while 'retrodos5.s' is source code of Retro DOS v5 kernel file 'PCDOS.SYS'.
    69                                  ; 'retrodos5.s' includes 'ibmdos7.bin' or IBMDOS.COM as binary file.)

   219                                  ; 1.26 03/03/82 Directory buffers searched as a circular queue, current buffer
   220                                  ;               is searched first when possible to minimize I/O
   221                                  ;      03/03/82 STORE routine optimized to tack on partial sector tail as
   222                                  ;               full sector write when file is growing

   228                                  ;                 Function call 47 - Get pointer to device table list
   229                                  ;                 Function call 48 - Assign CON AUX LIST
   230                                  ;      04/01/82 Spooler interrupt (INT 28) added.

   256                                  ;               (data segment) stashed in ES, INT int_fatal_abort routines must

   295                                  ; *************************************************************
   296                                  
   297                                  ; ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
   298                                  ; EQUATES
   299                                  
   300                                  ; Interrupt Entry Points:
   301                                  
   302                                  ; INTBASE:      ABORT
   303                                  ; INTBASE+4:    COMMAND
   304                                  ; INTBASE+8:    BASE EXIT ADDRESS
   305                                  ; INTBASE+C:    CONTROL-C ABORT
   306                                  ; INTBASE+10H:  FATAL ERROR ABORT
   307                                  ; INTBASE+14H:  BIOS DISK READ
   308                                  ; INTBASE+18H:  BIOS DISK WRITE
   309                                  ; INTBASE+1CH:  END BUT STAY RESIDENT (NOT SET BY DOS)
   310                                  ; INTBASE+20H:  SPOOLER INTERRUPT
   311                                  ; INTBASE+40H:  Long jump to CALL entry point
   312                                  
   313                                  ENTRYPOINTSEG   EQU     0Ch
   314                                  MAXDIF          EQU     0FFFh
   315                                  SAVEXIT         EQU     10
   316                                  ; 06/05/2019
   317                                  WRAPOFFSET	EQU	0FEF0h  ; (MISC.ASM, MSDOS 6.0, 1991)
   318                                  
   319                                         ; INCLUDE DOSSYM.ASM
   320                                         ; INCLUDE DEVSYM.ASM
   321                                  
   322                                  ; SUBTTL ^C, terminate/abort/exit and Hard error actions
   323                                  ; PAGE
   324                                  ; There are three kinds of context resets that can occur during normal DOS
   325                                  ; functioning:  ^C trap, terminate/abort/exit, and Hard-disk error.  These must
   326                                  ; be handles in a clean fashion that allows nested executions along with the
   327                                  ; ability to trap one's own errors.
   328                                  ;
   329                                  ; ^C trap - A process may elect to catch his own ^Cs.  This is achieved by
   330                                  ;           using the $GET_INTERRUPT_VECTOR and $SET_INTERRUPT_VECTOR as
   331                                  ;           follows:
   332                                  ;
   333                                  ;           $GET_INTERRUPT_VECTOR for INT int_ctrl_c
   334                                  ;           Save it in static memory.
   335                                  ;           $SET_INTERRUPT_VECTOR for INT int_ctrl_c
   336                                  ;
   337                                  ;           The interrupt service routine must preserve all registers and
   338                                  ;           return carry set iff the operation is to be aborted (via abort
   339                                  ;           system call), otherwise, carry is reset and the operation is
   340                                  ;           restarted.  ANY DEVIATION FROM THIS WILL LEAD TO UNRELIABLE
   341                                  ;           RESULTS.
   342                                  ;
   343                                  ;           To restore original ^C processing (done on terminate/abort/exit),
   344                                  ;           restore INT int_ctrl_c from the saved vector.
   345                                  ;
   346                                  ; Hard-disk error -- The interrupt service routine for INT int_fatal_abort must
   347                                  ;           also preserve registers and return one of three values in AL: 0 and
   348                                  ;           1 imply retry and ignore (???)  and 2 indicates an abort.  The user
   349                                  ;           himself is not to issue the abort, rather, the dos will do it for
   350                                  ;           him by simulating a normal abort/exit system call.  ANY DEVIATION
   351                                  ;           FROM THIS WILL LEAD TO UNRELIABLE RESULTS.
   352                                  ;
   353                                  ; terminate/abort/exit -- The user may not, under any circumstances trap an
   354                                  ;           abort call.  This is reserved for knowledgeable system programs.
   355                                  ;           ANY DEVIATION FROM THIS WILL LEAD TO UNRELIABLE RESULTS.
   356                                  
   357                                  ;SUBTTL SEGMENT DECLARATIONS
   358                                  
   359                                  ; The following are all of the segments used.  They are declared in the order
   360                                  ; that they should be placed in the executable
   361                                  
   362                                  ;
   363                                  ; segment ordering for MSDOS
   364                                  ;
   365                                  
   366                                  ;START           SEGMENT BYTE PUBLIC 'START'
   367                                  ;START           ENDS
   368                                  
   369                                  ;CONSTANTS       SEGMENT BYTE PUBLIC 'CONST'
   370                                  ;CONSTANTS       ENDS
   371                                  
   372                                  ;DATA            SEGMENT WORD PUBLIC 'DATA'
   373                                  ;DATA            ENDS
   374                                  
   375                                  ;CODE            SEGMENT BYTE PUBLIC 'CODE'
   376                                  ;CODE            ENDS
   377                                  
   378                                  ;LAST            SEGMENT BYTE PUBLIC 'LAST'
   379                                  ;LAST            ENDS
   380                                  
   381                                  ;DOSGROUP    GROUP   CODE,CONSTANTS,DATA,LAST
   382                                  
   383                                  ; The following segment is defined such that the data/const classes appear
   384                                  ; before the code class for ROMification
   385                                  
   386                                  ;START		SEGMENT BYTE PUBLIC 'START'
   387                                  ;           	ASSUME  CS:DOSGROUP,DS:NOTHING,ES:NOTHING,SS:NOTHING
   388                                  ;		JMP     DOSINIT
   389                                  ;START		ENDS
   390

   392                                  ; BPB.INC, MSDOS 6.0, 1991
   393                                  ;============================================================================
   394                                  ; 09/07/2018 - Retro DOS v3.0
   395                                  
   396                                  ;----+----+----+----+----+----+----+----+----+----+----+----+----+----+----;
   397                                  ;	     C	A  V  E  A  T	  P  R	O  G  R  A  M  M  E  R		   ;
   398                                  ;									   ;
   399                                  
   400                                  ;**	BIOS PARAMETER BLOCK DEFINITION
   401                                  ;
   402                                  ;	The BPB contains information about the disk structure. It dates
   403                                  ;	back to the earliest FAT systems and so FAT information is
   404                                  ;	intermingled with physical driver information.
   405                                  ;
   406                                  ;	A boot sector contains a BPB for its device; for other disks
   407                                  ;	the driver creates a BPB. DOS keeps copies of some of this
   408                                  ;	information in the DPB.
   409                                  ;
   410                                  ;	The BDS structure contains a BPB within it. 
   411                                  
   412                                  ; 01/01/2024
   413                                  %if 0
   414                                  
   415                                  struc A_BPB
   416                                  .BPB_BYTESPERSECTOR:	resw	1
   417                                  .BPB_SECTORSPERCLUSTER:	resb	1
   418                                  .BPB_RESERVEDSECTORS:	resw	1
   419                                  .BPB_NUMBEROFFATS:	resb	1
   420                                  .BPB_ROOTENTRIES: 	resw	1
   421                                  .BPB_TOTALSECTORS:	resw	1
   422                                  .BPB_MEDIADESCRIPTOR:	resb	1
   423                                  .BPB_SECTORSPERFAT:	resw	1
   424                                  .BPB_SECTORSPERTRACK:	resw	1
   425                                  .BPB_HEADS:		resw	1
   426                                  .BPB_HIDDENSECTORS:	resw	1
   427                                  			resw	1
   428                                  .BPB_BIGTOTALSECTORS:	resw	1
   429                                  			resw	1
   430                                  			resb	6	; NOTE:  many times these
   431                                  ;					; 	 6 bytes are omitted
   432                                  ;					;	 when BPB manipulations
   433                                  ;					;	 are performed!
   434                                  .size:
   435                                  endstruc
   436                                  
   437                                  %else
   438                                  
   439                                  ; 01/01/2024 - Retro DOS v5.0	
   440                                  
   441                                  struc A_BPB
   442 00000000 ????                    .BYTESPERSECTOR:    resw 1
   443 00000002 ??                      .SECTORSPERCLUSTER: resb 1
   444 00000003 ????                    .RESERVEDSECTORS:   resw 1
   445 00000005 ??                      .NUMBEROFFATS:	    resb 1
   446 00000006 ????                    .ROOTENTRIES:	    resw 1
   447 00000008 ????                    .TOTALSECTORS:	    resw 1
   448 0000000A ??                      .MEDIADESCRIPTOR:   resb 1
   449 0000000B ????                    .SECTORSPERFAT:	    resw 1
   450 0000000D ????                    .SECTORSPERTRACK:   resw 1

   477                                  ; <Disk I/O Buffer Header>
   478                                  
   479                                  ;----+----+----+----+----+----+----+----+----+----+----+----+----+----+----;
   480                                  ;	     C	A  V  E  A  T	  P  R	O  G  R  A  M  M  E  R		   ;
   481                                  ;									   ;
   482                                  
   483                                  ; Field definition for I/O buffer information
   484                                  
   485                                  	; 03/01/2024 - Retro DOS v5.0 (PCDOS 7.1 IBMDOS.COM)
   486                                  
   487                                  struc BUFFINFO
   488 00000000 ????                    .buf_next:	resw 1		; Pointer to next buffer in list
   489 00000002 ????                    .buf_prev:	resw 1		; Pointer to prev buffer in list
   490 00000004 ??                      .buf_ID:	resb 1		; Drive of buffer (bit 7 = 0)
   491                                  				; SFT table index (bit 7 = 1)
   492                                  				; = FFH if buffer free
   493 00000005 ??                      .buf_flags:	resb 1		; Bit 7 = 1 if Remote file buffer
   494                                  				;	= 0 if Local device buffer
   495                                  				; Bit 6 = 1 if buffer dirty
   496                                  				; Bit 5 = Reserved
   497                                  				; Bit 4 = Search bit (bit 7 = 1)
   498                                  				; Bit 3 = 1 if buffer is DATA
   499                                  				; Bit 2 = 1 if buffer is DIR
   500                                  				; Bit 1 = 1 if buffer is FAT
   501                                  				; Bit 0 = Reserved
   502 00000006 ????????                .buf_sector:	resd 1		; Sector number of buffer (flags bit 7 = 0)
   503                                  ; The next two items are often refed as a word (flags bit 7 = 0)
   504 0000000A ??                      .buf_wrtcnt:	resb 1		; For FAT sectors, # times sector written out
   505 0000000B ????                    .buf_wrtcntinc:	resw 1		; "   "     "   , # sectors between each write
   506 0000000D ????                    		resw 1 ; * ; 03/01/2024 ; PCDOS 7.1
   507                                  			   ; hw of sectors per FAT
   508 0000000F ????????                .buf_DPB:	resd 1		; Pointer to drive parameters
   509 00000013 ????                    .buf_fill:	resw 1		; How full buffer is (flags bit 7 = 1)
   510 00000015 ??                      .buf_reserved:	resb 1		; make DWORD boundary for 386
   511 00000016 ????                    		resw 1 ; * ; 03/01/2024 ; PCDOS 7.1
   512                                  			   ; reserved word for dword boundary
   513                                  .size:	; 20 bytes ; MSDOS 5.0 to 6.22
   514                                  	; 24 bytes ; PCDOS 7.1 ; 03/01/2024
   515                                  endstruc
   516                                  
   517                                  %define buf_offset	BUFFINFO.buf_sector ; 22/07/2019
   518                                  				;For buf_flags bit 7 = 1, this is the byte
   519                                  				;offset of the start of the buffer in
   520                                  				;the file pointed to by buf_ID. Thus
   521                                  				;the buffer starts at location
   522                                  				;buf_offset in the file and contains
   523                                  				;buf_fill bytes.
   524                                  
   525                                  BUFINSIZ        EQU     BUFFINFO.size
   526                                  
   527                                  buf_Free	EQU	0FFh	; buf_id of free buffer
   528                                  
   529                                  ;Flag byte masks
   530                                  buf_isnet	EQU	10000000B
   531                                  buf_dirty	EQU	01000000B
   532                                  ;***
   533                                  buf_visit	EQU	00100000B
   534                                  ;***
   535                                  buf_snbuf	EQU	00010000B
   536                                  
   537                                  buf_isDATA	EQU	00001000B
   538                                  buf_isDIR	EQU	00000100B
   539                                  buf_isFAT	EQU	00000010B
   540                                  buf_type_0	EQU	11110001B	; AND sets type to "none"
   541                                  
   542                                  buf_NetID	EQU	BUFINSIZ
   543

   545                                  ;            C  A  V  E  A  T     P  R  O  G  R  A  M  M  E  R             ;

   557                                  c_CR	    EQU     0Dh 	; ^M ASCII carriage return
   558                                  c_LF	    EQU     0Ah 	; ^J ASCII linefeed

   560                                  c_NAK	    EQU     15h 	; ^U ASCII negative acknowledge
   561                                  c_ETX	    EQU     03h 	; ^C ASCII end of text
   562                                  c_HT	    EQU     09h 	; ^I ASCII tab

   565                                  ; Location of user registers relative user stack pointer
   566

   569 00000002 ????                    .user_BX: resw 1
   570 00000004 ????                    .user_CX: resw 1
   571 00000006 ????                    .user_DX: resw 1
   572 00000008 ????                    .user_SI: resw 1

   580                                  .size:
   581                                  endstruc
   582                                  
   583                                  ; ---- <Disk map> ----
   584                                  
   585                                  ;	MSDOS partitions the disk into 4 sections:
   586                                  ;
   587                                  ;  phys sector 0:   +-------------------+
   588                                  ;	|	    | boot/reserved	|
   589                                  ;	|	    +-------------------+
   590                                  ;	|	    |  File allocation	|
   591                                  ;	v	    |	   table(s)	|
   592                                  ;		    |  (multiple copies |
   593                                  ;		    |	  are kept)	|
   594                                  ;		    +-------------------+
   595                                  ;		    |	  Directory	|
   596                                  ;		    +-------------------+
   597                                  ;		    |	  File space	|
   598                                  ;		    +-------------------+
   599                                  ;		    |	Unaddressable	|
   600                                  ;		    |  (to end of disk) |
   601                                  ;		    +-------------------+
   602                                  ;
   603                                  ; All partition boundaries are sector boundaries. The size of the FAT is
   604                                  ; adjusted to maximize the file space addressable.
   605                                  
   606                                  ; <File allocation Table information>
   607                                  
   608                                  ; The File Allocation Table uses a 12-bit entry for each allocation unit on
   609                                  ; the disk. These entries are packed, two for every three bytes. The contents
   610                                  ; of entry number N is found by 1) multiplying N by 1.5; 2) adding the result
   611                                  ; to the base address of the Allocation Table; 3) fetching the 16-bit word
   612                                  ; at this address; 4) If N was odd (so that N*1.5 was not an integer), shift
   613                                  ; the word right four bits; 5) mask to 12 bits (AND with 0FFF hex). Entry
   614                                  ; number zero is used as an end-of-file trap in the OS and is passed to the
   615                                  ; BIOS to help determine disk format. Entry 1 is reserved for future use.
   616                                  ; The first available allocation unit is assigned entry number two, and even
   617                                  ; though it is the first, is called cluster 2. Entries greater than 0FF8H
   618                                  ; (12-bit fats) or 0FFF8H (16-bit fats) are end of file marks; entries of zero
   619                                  ; are unallocated. Otherwise, the contents of a FAT entry is the number of
   620                                  ; the next cluster in the file.
   621                                  ;
   622                                  ; Clusters with bad sectors are tagged with FF7H. Any non-zero number would
   623                                  ; do because these clusters show as allocated, but are not part of any
   624                                  ; allocation chain and thus will never be allocated to a file. A particular
   625                                  ; number is selected so that disk checking programs know what to do (ie. a
   626                                  ; cluster with entry FF7H which is not in a chain is not an error).
   627                                  
   628                                  ;**	Character Type Flags
   629                                  ;
   630                                  ;	These flags are used in a lookup table indexed by the character code.
   631                                  ;	They're used to quickly classify characters when parsing paths.
   632                                  ;	I think that these are only used to parse FCBs - jgl
   633                                  
   634                                  FCHK	equ 1	; I think this means "normal name char, no chks needed" -jgl
   635                                  FDELIM	equ 2	; is a delimiter
   636                                  FSPCHK	equ 4	; set if character is not a space or equivalent
   637                                  FFCB	equ 8	; is valid in an FCB
   638                                  
   639                                  ;** Bit definitions for DOS_FLAG
   640                                  ;
   641                                  ; Bit 0 - this is set when a $open call is made from $exec. This is used in
   642                                  ;	  $open to indicate to the redirector that this open is being made
   643                                  ;	  by an exec call.
   644                                  ;
   645                                  ; Bit 2
   646                                  ;
   647                                  ; M003, M027:
   648                                  ;
   649                                  ; The start up code of MS PASCAL 3.2 programs depend on the 1M address wrap 
   650                                  ; if they load below 64K. This is a likely possiblity in DOS 5.x with DOS in
   651                                  ; the HMA. By default DOS will turn A20 OFF before Xferring control to the
   652                                  ; user program in the case of an Exec call. The next call to DOS will turn
   653                                  ; A20 line ON. It has been observed that MS PASCAL 3.2 start up does an int
   654                                  ; 21 ah=25h call before executing the faulty code. This will turn A20 On. 
   655                                  ; In order to support this we will set Bit 2 of this flag in the DOS exec
   656                                  ; call (msproc.asm) if DOS is running in the HMA. In $set_interrupt_vector in
   657                                  ; getset.asm A20OFF_COUNT is set to 1 if bit 2 of DOS_FLAG was previously set 
   658                                  ; by a call to exec and if A20OFF_COUNT is 0. In msdisp.asm, if A20OFF_COUNT 
   659                                  ; is non zero then A20 will be turned OFF before returning to the user. 
   660                                  ; Bit 2 will be unconditionally cleared here.
   661                                  ;
   662                                  ; M009, M027:
   663                                  ;
   664                                  ; Mace utilities MKEYRATE.COM version 1.0 copyright 1987 is an execpacked 
   665                                  ; program converted to a com file. Therefore if DOS is loaded high and if 
   666                                  ; this program is loaded below 64K it will blurt out "packed file is corrupt".
   667                                  ; This program does an int 21 ah=49h before executing the buggy execpacked
   668                                  ; code. This int21 call turns a20 on and hence the problem. In $dealloc
   669                                  ; alloc.asm A20OFF_COUNT is set to 1 if bit 2 of DOS_FLAG was previously set 
   670                                  ; by a call to exec and if A20OFF_COUNT is 0. In msdisp.asm, if A20OFF_COUNT 
   671                                  ; is non zero then A20 will be turned OFF before returning to the user. 
   672                                  ; Bit 2 will be unconditionally cleared here.
   673                                  
   674                                  EXECOPEN	EQU	00000001b	; bit 0 of DOS_FLAG
   675                                  SUPPRESS_WINA20	EQU	00000010b	; M025
   676                                  EXECA20OFF	EQU	00000100b	; bit 2 of DOS_FLAG
   677                                  
   678                                  ;============================================================================
   679                                  ; VECTOR.INC, MSDOS 6.0, 1991

   682

   684                                  
   685                                  ; <interrupt definitions>
   686                                  
   687                                  INTTAB          EQU     20H
   688                                  INTBASE         EQU     4 * INTTAB
   689                                  ENTRYPOINT      EQU     INTBASE+40H

   708                                  					; resident

   714                                  int_IBM 	    EQU     int_abort+10; critical section maintenance
   715                                  ;									   ;

   717                                  ;----+----+----+----+----+----+----+----+----+----+----+----+----+----+----;
   718                                  ;	ELSE
   719                                  ;int_abort	    EQU     INTTAB	; abort process
   720                                  ;int_command	    EQU     int_abort+1 ; call MSDOS
   721                                  ;int_terminate	    EQU     ALTTAB	; int to terminate address
   722                                  ;int_ctrl_c	    EQU     int_terminate+1 ; ^c trapper
   723                                  ;int_fatal_abort    EQU     int_terminate+2 ; hard disk error
   724                                  ;int_disk_read	    EQU     int_abort+5 ; logical sector disk read
   725                                  ;int_disk_write	    EQU     int_abort+6 ; logical sector disk write
   726                                  ;int_keep_process   EQU     int_abort+7 ; terminate program and stay resident
   727                                  ;----+----+----+----+----+----+----+----+----+----+----+----+----+----+----;

   735                                  ;	ENDIF

   760                                  ; BREAK <Directory entry>
   761                                  
   762                                  ;
   763                                  ;       +---------------------------+
   764                                  ;       |  (12 BYTE) filename/ext   |       0       0
   765                                  ;       +---------------------------+
   766                                  ;       |     (BYTE) attributes     |       11      B
   767                                  ;       +---------------------------+
   768                                  ;       |    (10 BYTE) reserved     |       12      C
   769                                  ;       +---------------------------+
   770                                  ;       | (WORD) time of last write |       22      16
   771                                  ;       +---------------------------+
   772                                  ;       | (WORD) date of last write |       24      18
   773                                  ;       +---------------------------+
   774                                  ;       |   (WORD) First cluster    |       26      1A
   775                                  ;       +---------------------------+
   776                                  ;       |     (DWORD) file size     |       28      1C
   777                                  ;       +---------------------------+
   778                                  ;
   779                                  ;   First byte of filename  = E5 -> free directory entry
   780                                  ;                           = 00 -> end of allocated directory
   781                                  ;   Time:   Bits 0-4=seconds/2, bits 5-10=minute, 11-15=hour
   782                                  ;   Date:   Bits 0-4=day, bits 5-8=month, bits 9-15=year-1980
   783                                  
   784                                  ; 01/01/2024
   785                                  %if 0
   786                                  
   787                                  struc dir_entry
   788                                  .dir_name:	resb 11			; file name
   789                                  .dir_attr:	resb 1			; attribute bits
   790                                  .dir_codepg:	resw 1			; code page DOS 4.00
   791                                  .dir_extcluster: resw 1			; extended attribute starting cluster
   792                                  .dir_attr2:	resb 1			; reserved
   793                                  .dir_pad:	resb 5			; reserved for expansion
   794                                  .dir_time:	resw 1			; time of last write
   795                                  .dir_date:	resw 1			; date of last write
   796                                  .dir_first:	resw 1			; first allocation unit of file
   797                                  .dir_size_l:	resw 1			; low 16 bits of file size
   798                                  .dir_size_h:	resw 1			; high 16 bits of file size
   799                                  .size:
   800                                  endstruc
   801                                  
   802                                  %else
   803                                  
   804                                  ; 01/01/2024 - Retro DOS v5.0 (*)	
   805                                  
   806                                  struc dir_entry
   807 00000000 <res Bh>                .dir_name:	resb 11			; file name (short file name)
   808 0000000B ??                      .dir_attr:	resb 1			; file attributes (*)
   809 0000000C ??                      .dir_nt_res:	resb 1			; reserved for use by Windows NT. 0 
   810                                  .dir_pad:	;resb 7			; (creation time, last access date
   811                                  					;  for use by Windows) 
   812                                  .dir_crttime_tenth:
   813 0000000D ??                      		resb 1
   814 0000000E ????                    .dir_ctrtime:	resw 1
   815 00000010 ????                    .dir_crtdate:	resw 1
   816                                  .dir_lstaccdate:
   817 00000012 ????                    		resw 1
   818 00000014 ????                    .dir_fclus_hi:	resw 1	; FAT32	fs	; high word of first cluster number
   819 00000016 ????                    .dir_time:	resw 1			; time of last write
   820 00000018 ????                    .dir_date:	resw 1			; date of last write
   821                                  .dir_fclus:				
   822 0000001A ????                    .dir_first:	resw 1			; first cluster (alloc. unit) of file
   823                                  .dir_file_size:
   824 0000001C ????                    .dir_size_l:	resw 1			; low 16 bits of file size
   825 0000001E ????                    .dir_size_h:	resw 1			; high 16 bits of file size
   826                                  .size:
   827                                  endstruc	
   828                                  
   829                                  %endif
   830                                  
   831                                  attr_read_only      EQU      1h
   832                                  attr_hidden         EQU      2h
   833                                  attr_system         EQU      4h
   834                                  attr_volume_id      EQU      8h
   835                                  attr_directory      EQU     10h
   836                                  attr_archive        EQU     20h
   837                                  attr_device	    EQU     40h	; This is a VERY special bit.
   838                                  				;   NO directory entry on a disk EVER
   839                                  				;   has this bit set. It is set non-zero
   840                                  				;   when a device is found by GETPATH
   841                                  
   842                                  attr_all            EQU     attr_hidden+attr_system+attr_directory
   843                                                                          ; OR of hard attributes for FINDENTRY
   844                                  
   845                                  attr_ignore         EQU     attr_read_only+attr_archive
   846                                                                          ; ignore this(ese) attribute(s)
   847                                                                          ; during search first/next
   848                                  
   849                                  attr_changeable     EQU     attr_read_only+attr_hidden+attr_system+attr_archive
   850                                                                          ; changeable via CHMOD
   851                                  
   852                                  DIRFREE		equ	0E5h	; stored in dir_name[0] to indicate free slot

   864                                  ; 24/04/2019 - Retro DOS v4.0
   865                                  
   866                                  ; 19/07/2018 - Retro DOS v3.0 (DPB.INC, MSDOS 3.3, 1987)
   867                                  ; 07/07/2018 - Retro DOS v3.0 (DPB.INC, MSDOS 6.0, 1991)
   868                                  
   869                                  ; ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
   870                                  ;**	DPB - Drive Parameter Block
   871                                  ;
   872                                  ;	BUGBUG - this isn't authorative - it's my probably incomplete and
   873                                  ;	possibly inaccurate deductions from code study... - jgl
   874                                  ;
   875                                  ;	The DPB is DOS's main structure for describing block devices.
   876                                  ;	It contains info about the "Drive" intermingled with info about
   877                                  ;	the FAT file system which is presumably on the drive.  I don't know
   878                                  ;	how those fields are used if it's not the FAT file system - BUGBUG
   879                                  ;
   880                                  ;	The DPBs are statically allocated and chained off of DPBHead.
   881                                  ;	Users scan this chain looking for a match on DPB_DRIVE.
   882                                  ;	The DPBs are built at init time from info in the SYSDEV structure.
   883                                  ; ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
   884                                  
   885                                  ; 01/01/2024
   886                                  %if 0
   887                                  
   888                                  struc	DPB
   889                                  .DRIVE:		resb 1		; Logical drive # assoc with DPB (A=0,B=1,...)
   890                                  .UNIT:		resb 1		; Driver unit number of DPB
   891                                  .SECTOR_SIZE:	resw 1		; Size of physical sector in bytes
   892                                  .CLUSTER_MASK:	resb 1		; Sectors/cluster - 1
   893                                  .CLUSTER_SHIFT:	resb 1		; Log2 of sectors/cluster
   894                                  .FIRST_FAT:	resw 1		; Starting record of FATs
   895                                  .FAT_COUNT:	resb 1		; Number of FATs for this drive
   896                                  .ROOT_ENTRIES:	resw 1		; Number of directory entries
   897                                  .FIRST_SECTOR:	resw 1		; First sector of first cluster
   898                                  .MAX_CLUSTER:	resw 1		; Number of clusters on drive + 1
   899                                  ; MSDOS 3.3
   900                                  ;.FAT_SIZE:	resb 1		; Number of records occupied by FAT
   901                                  ; MSDOS 6.0
   902                                  .FAT_SIZE:	resw 1		; Number of records occupied by FAT
   903                                  .DIR_SECTOR:	resw 1		; Starting record of directory
   904                                  .DRIVER_ADDR:	resd 1		; Pointer to driver
   905                                  .MEDIA:		resb 1		; Media byte
   906                                  .FIRST_ACCESS:	resb 1		; This is initialized to -1 to force a media
   907                                  				; check the first time this DPB is used
   908                                  .NEXT_DPB:	resd 1		; Pointer to next Drive parameter block
   909                                  .NEXT_FREE:	resw 1		; Cluster # of last allocated cluster
   910                                  .FREE_CNT:	resw 1		; Count of free clusters, -1 if unknown
   911                                  .size:
   912                                  endstruc
   913                                  
   914                                  %else
   915                                  
   916                                  ; 01/01/2024 - Retro DOS v5.0 (PCDOS 7.1)
   917

   919 00000000 ??                      .DRIVE:		resb 1	; 0	; Logical drive # assoc with DPB (A=0,B=1,...)
   920 00000001 ??                      .UNIT:		resb 1	; 1	; Driver unit number of DPB
   921 00000002 ????                    .SECTOR_SIZE:	resw 1	; 2	; Size of physical sector in bytes
   922 00000004 ??                      .CLUSTER_MASK:	resb 1	; 4	; Sectors/cluster - 1
   923 00000005 ??                      .CLUSTER_SHIFT:	resb 1	; 5	; Log2 of sectors/cluster
   924 00000006 ????                    .FIRST_FAT:	resw 1	; 6	; Starting record of FATs
   925 00000008 ??                      .FAT_COUNT:	resb 1	; 8	; Number of FATs for this drive
   926 00000009 ????                    .ROOT_ENTRIES:	resw 1	; 9	; Number of directory entries
   927 0000000B ????                    .FIRST_SECTOR:	resw 1	; 11	; First sector of first cluster
   928 0000000D ????                    .MAX_CLUSTER:	resw 1	; 13	; Number of clusters on drive + 1
   929 0000000F ????                    .FAT_SIZE:	resw 1	; 15	; Number of records occupied by FAT
   930 00000011 ????                    .DIR_SECTOR:	resw 1	; 17	; Starting record of directory
   931 00000013 ????????                .DRIVER_ADDR:	resd 1  ; 19	; Pointer to driver
   932 00000017 ??                      .MEDIA:		resb 1	; 23	; Media byte
   933 00000018 ??                      .FIRST_ACCESS:	resb 1	; 24	; This is initialized to -1 to force a media
   934                                  				; check the first time this DPB is used
   935 00000019 ????????                .NEXT_DPB:	resd 1	; 25	; Pointer to next Drive parameter block
   936 0000001D ????                    .NEXT_FREE:	resw 1	; 29	; Cluster # of last allocated cluster
   937 0000001F ????                    .FREE_CNT:	resw 1	; 31	; Count of free clusters, -1 if unknown
   938                                  ; FAT32 fs ; 01/01/2024
   939                                  ; ref: https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/
   940                                  ;      First_steps_towards_system_programming_under_MS-DOS_7/Appendix
   941                                  ;   -- A.03-1. Structure of Drive Parameters Blocks (DPB) ---
   942 00000021 ????                    .FREE_CNT_HW:	resw 1	; 33	; High word of free cluster count
   943 00000023 ????                    .EXT_FLAGS:	resw 1	; 35	; FAT32 extended flags (active FAT number)
   944 00000025 ????                    .FSINFO_SECTOR:	resw 1	; 37	; (FAT32 fs) FSINFO structure sector address

   947 0000002D ????????                .LAST_CLUSTER:	resd 1	; 45	; The last cluster number
   948 00000031 ????????                .FAT32_SIZE:	resd 1	; 49	; Number of FAT sectors (for FAT32 fs)	 
   949 00000035 ????????                .ROOT_CLUSTER:	resd 1	; 53	; Root directory's cluster number (FAT32 fs)
   950                                  ; 01/01/2024 - Retro DOS v5.0
   951 00000039 ????????                .FAT32_NXTFREE:	resd 1  ; 57	; The next free cluster (for FAT32 fs)
   952                                  .size:		; 61 bytes ; 01/01/2024 (PCDOS 7.1)

   976                                  ; ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
   977                                  ;**	SF.INC - System File Table
   978                                  ;
   979                                  ;   AN000   version 4.00   Jan. 1988
   980                                  ;   AN003   PTM 3680 --  make NAME offset the same as before (<=3.30)
   981                                  ;   AN009   PTM 3839	 reorder SFT for MS WINDOWS
   982                                  ; ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
   983                                  ;**	System File Table SuperStructure
   984                                  ;
   985                                  ;	The system file table entries are allocated in contiguous groups.
   986                                  ;	There may be more than one such groups; the SF "superstructure"
   987                                  ;	tracks the groups.
   988                                  ; ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
   989                                  
   990                                  struc	SFT
   991 00000000 ????????                .SFLink:	resd 1
   992 00000004 ????                    .SFCount:	resw 1		; number of entries
   993 00000006 ????                    .SFTable:	resw 1		; beginning of array of the following
   994                                  .size:
   995                                  endstruc
   996                                  
   997                                  ; ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
   998                                  ;**	System file table entry
   999                                  ;
  1000                                  ;	These are the structures which are at SFTABLE in the SF structure.
  1001                                  ; ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
  1002                                  
  1003                                  ; 01/01/2024 - Retro DOS v5.0
  1004                                  ; 25/04/2019 - Retro DOS v4.0
  1005                                  
  1006                                  struc SF_ENTRY
  1007 00000000 ????                    .sf_ref_count:	resw 1	; 0	; number of processes sharing entry
  1008                                  				;   if FCB then ref count
  1009 00000002 ????                    .sf_mode:	resw 1	; 2	; mode of access or high bit on if FCB
  1010 00000004 ??                      .sf_attr:	resb 1	; 4	; attribute of file
  1011 00000005 ????                    .sf_flags:	resw 1	; 5	;Bits 8-15
  1012                                  				; Bit 15 = 1 if remote file
  1013                                  				;	 = 0 if local file or device
  1014                                  				; Bit 14 = 1 if date/time is not to be
  1015                                  				;   set from clock at CLOSE.  Set by
  1016                                  				;   FILETIMES and FCB_CLOSE.  Reset by
  1017                                  				;   other reseters of the dirty bit
  1018                                  				;   (WRITE)
  1019                                  				; Bit 13 = Pipe bit (reserved)
  1020                                  				;
  1021                                  				; Bits 0-7 (old FCB_devid bits)
  1022                                  				; If remote file or local file, bit
  1023                                  				; 6=0 if dirty Device ID number, bits
  1024                                  				; 0-5 if local file.
  1025                                  				; bit 7=0 for local file, bit 7
  1026                                  				;      =1 for local I/O device
  1027                                  				; If local I/O device, bit 6=0 if EOF (input)
  1028                                  				;		Bit 5=1 if Raw mode
  1029                                  				;		Bit 0=1 if console input device
  1030                                  				;		Bit 1=1 if console output device
  1031                                  				;		Bit 2=1 if null device
  1032                                  				;		Bit 3=1 if clock device
  1033 00000007 ????????                .sf_devptr:	resd	1 ; 7	; Points to DPB if local file, points
  1034                                  				; to device header if local device,
  1035                                  				; points to net device header if
  1036                                  				; remote
  1037 0000000B ????                    .sf_firclus:	resw	1 ; 11	; First cluster of file (bit 15 = 0)
  1038 0000000D ????                    .sf_time:	resw	1 ; 13	; Time associated with file
  1039 0000000F ????                    .sf_date:	resw	1 ; 15	; Date associated with file
  1040 00000011 ????????                .sf_size:	resd 	1 ; 17	; Size associated with file
  1041 00000015 ????????                .sf_position:	resd	1 ; 21	; Read/Write pointer or LRU count for FCBs
  1042                                  
  1043                                  ; Starting here, the next 7 bytes may be used by the file system to store
  1044                                  ; an ID
  1045                                  
  1046                                  ; 09/07/2018 - Retro DOS v3.0
  1047                                  
  1048                                  ; MSDOS 3.3 SF.INC, 1987
  1049                                  ;.sf_cluspos:	resw	1	; Position of last cluster accessed
  1050                                  ;.sf_lstclus	resw	1	; Last cluster accessed
  1051                                  ;.sf_dirsec:	resw	1	; Sector number of directory sector
  1052                                  ;				; for this file
  1053                                  ;.sf_dirpos:	resb	1	; Offset of this entry in the above
  1054                                  
  1055                                  ; MSDOS 6.0, SF.INC, 1991
  1056 00000019 ????                    .sf_cluspos:	resw	1 ; 25	; Position of last cluster accessed
  1057 0000001B ????????                .sf_dirsec:	resd	1 ; 27	; Sector number of directory sector
  1058                                  				; for this file
  1059 0000001F ??                      .sf_dirpos:	resb	1 ; 31	; Offset of this entry in the above
  1060                                  
  1061                                  ; End of 7 bytes of file-system specific info.
  1062                                  
  1063 00000020 <res Bh>                .sf_name:	resb	11 ; 32	; 11 character name that is in the
  1064                                  				; directory entry.  This is used by
  1065                                  				; close to detect file deleted and
  1066                                  				; disk changed errors.
  1067                                  ; SHARING INFO
  1068 0000002B ????????                .sf_chain:	resd	1 ; 43	; link to next SF
  1069 0000002F ????                    .sf_UID:	resw	1 ; 47
  1070 00000031 ????                    .sf_PID:	resw	1 ; 49	; owner process identifier (PSP segment) 
  1071 00000033 ????                    .sf_MFT:	resw	1 ; 51
  1072                                  
  1073                                  ; MSDOS 6.0, SF.INC, 1991
  1074 00000035 ????                    .sf_lstclus:	resw	1 ; 53	;AN009; Last cluster accessed
  1075 00000037 ????????                .sf_IFS_HDR:	resd	1 ; 55	; pointer to IFS drive or 0:0 for files
  1076                                  
  1077                                  .size:
  1078                                  endstruc
  1079                                  
  1080                                  ; 20/07/2018
  1081                                  ; MSDOS 3.3, SF.INC, 1987
  1082                                  %define sf_netid   SF_ENTRY.sf_cluspos    ; byte
  1083                                  %define sf_OpenAge SF_ENTRY.sf_position+2 ; word
  1084                                  %define sf_LRU	   SF_ENTRY.sf_position	  ; word
  1085                                  ; MSDOS 6.0, SF.INC, 1991
  1086                                  %define sf_fsda	     SF_ENTRY.sf_cluspos  ; byte ;DOS 4.00
  1087                                  %define sf_serial_ID SF_ENTRY.sf_firclus  ; word ;DOS 4.00
  1088                                  
  1089                                  ; 19/07/2018
  1090                                  ; MSDOS 3.3, SF.INC, 1987
  1091                                  
  1092                                  sf_default_number  EQU	5
  1093                                  
  1094                                  ; Note that we need to mark an SFT as being busy for OPEN/CREATE.  This is
  1095                                  ; because an INT 24 may prevent us from 'freeing' it.  We mark this as such
  1096                                  ; by placing a -1 in the ref_count field.
  1097                                  
  1098                                  sf_busy EQU -1
  1099                                  
  1100                                  ; mode mask for FCB detection
  1101                                  sf_isFCB		EQU	1000000000000000B
  1102                                  
  1103                                  ; Flag word masks
  1104                                  sf_isnet		EQU	1000000000000000B
  1105                                  sf_close_nodate 	EQU	0100000000000000B
  1106                                  sf_pipe 		EQU	0010000000000000B
  1107                                  sf_no_inherit		EQU	0001000000000000B
  1108                                  sf_net_spool		EQU	0000100000000000B
  1109                                  
  1110                                  ; 25/04/2019
  1111                                  sf_entry_size equ SF_ENTRY.size ; 59 (MSDOS 6.0)
  1112                                  
  1113                                  ; ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
  1114                                  ; Local file/device flag masks
  1115                                  ; ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
  1116                                  
  1117                                  devid_file_clean        EQU     40h     ; true if file and not written
  1118                                  devid_file_mask_drive   EQU     3Fh     ; mask for drive number
  1119                                  
  1120                                  devid_device            EQU     80h     ; true if a device
  1121                                  devid_device_EOF        EQU     40h     ; true if end of file reached
  1122                                  devid_device_raw        EQU     20h     ; true if in raw mode
  1123                                  devid_device_special    EQU     10h     ; true if special device
  1124                                  devid_device_clock      EQU     08h     ; true if clock device
  1125                                  devid_device_null       EQU     04h     ; true if null device
  1126                                  devid_device_con_out    EQU     02h     ; true if console output
  1127                                  devid_device_con_in     EQU     01h     ; true if consle input
  1128                                  
  1129                                  ; ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
  1130                                  ; structure of devid field as returned by IOCTL is:
  1131                                  ;
  1132                                  ;       BIT     7   6   5   4   3   2   1   0
  1133                                  ;             |---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|
  1134                                  ;             | I | E | R | S | I | I | I | I |
  1135                                  ;             | S | O | A | P | S | S | S | S |
  1136                                  ;             | D | F | W | E | C | N | C | C |
  1137                                  ;             | E |   |   | C | L | U | O | I |
  1138                                  ;             | V |   |   | L | K | L | T | N |
  1139                                  ;             |---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|
  1140                                  ;       ISDEV = 1 if this channel is a device
  1141                                  ;             = 0 if this channel is a disk file
  1142                                  ;
  1143                                  ;       If ISDEV = 1
  1144                                  ;
  1145                                  ;             EOF = 0 if End Of File on input
  1146                                  ;             RAW = 1 if this device is in Raw mode
  1147                                  ;                 = 0 if this device is cooked
  1148                                  ;             ISCLK = 1 if this device is the clock device
  1149                                  ;             ISNUL = 1 if this device is the null device
  1150                                  ;             ISCOT = 1 if this device is the console output
  1151                                  ;             ISCIN = 1 if this device is the console input
  1152                                  ;
  1153                                  ;       If ISDEV = 0
  1154                                  ;             EOF = 0 if channel has been written
  1155                                  ;             Bits 0-5  are  the  block  device  number  for
  1156                                  ;                 the channel (0 = A, 1 = B, ...)
  1157                                  ; ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
  1158                                  
  1159                                  devid_ISDEV     EQU     80h
  1160                                  devid_EOF       EQU     40h
  1161                                  devid_RAW       EQU     20h
  1162                                  devid_SPECIAL   EQU     10H
  1163                                  devid_ISCLK     EQU     08h
  1164                                  devid_ISNUL     EQU     04h
  1165                                  devid_ISCOT     EQU     02h
  1166                                  devid_ISCIN     EQU     01h
  1167                                  
  1168                                  devid_block_dev EQU     1Fh             ; mask for block device number
  1169

  1177                                  ; BREAK <Process data block>
  1178                                  ; ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
  1179                                  ;**	Process data block (otherwise known as program header)
  1180                                  ;
  1181                                  
  1182                                  ;	These offset are documented in the MSDOS Encyclopedia, so nothing
  1183                                  ;	can be rearranged here, ever. Reserved areas are probably safe
  1184                                  ;	for use.
  1185                                  ; ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
  1186                                  
  1187                                  FILPERPROC	EQU     20
  1188

  1199 0000002C ????                    .ENVIRON:	resw 1		; segment address of environment

  1207 00000040 ????                    .Version:	resw 1	; MSDOS 6.0 ; DOS version reported to this app
  1208 00000042 <res Eh>                .PAD1:		resb 14 ; 0Eh

  1210 00000055 ??????????????          .PAD2:		resb 7		; reserved so FCB 1 can be used as
  1211                                  				;  an extended FCB
  1212                                  ;endstruc 	; MSDOS 3.3
  1213                                  	  	; MSDOS 6.0
  1214 0000005C <res 10h>               .FCB1:		resb 16 ; 10h	; default FCB 1

  1225                                  ;**	EXE.INC - Definitions for the EXEC command and EXE files
  1226                                  ; ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
  1227                                  ; The following get used as arguments to the EXEC system call.  They indicate
  1228                                  ; whether or not the program is executed or whether or not a program header
  1229                                  ; gets created.

  1232                                  exec_func_overlay    EQU 2	; overlay bit
  1233

  1684                                  .Date_tim_format:
  1685 00000000 ????                    		RESW 1		; 0-USA, 1-EUR, 2-JAP
  1686                                  .Currency_sym:
  1687 00000002 ??????????              		RESB 5		; Currency Symbol 5 bytes
  1688                                  .Thous_sep:
  1689 00000007 ????                    		RESB 2		; Thousands separator 2 bytes
  1690                                  .Decimal_sep:
  1691 00000009 ????                    		RESB 2		; Decimal separator 2 bytes
  1692                                  .Date_sep:
  1693 0000000B ????                    		RESB 2		; Date separator 2 bytes
  1694                                  .Time_sep:
  1695 0000000D ????                    		RESB 2		; Time separator 2 bytes
  1696                                  .Bit_field:	
  1697 0000000F ??                      		RESB 1		; Bit values
  1698                                                                     ;   Bit 0 = 0 if currency symbol first
  1699                                                                     ;         = 1 if currency symbol last
  1700                                                                     ;   Bit 1 = 0 if No space after currency symbol
  1701                                                                     ;         = 1 if space after currency symbol
  1702                                  .Currency_cents:

  1704                                  .Time_24:
  1705 00000011 ??                      		RESB 	1	; 1 if 24 hour time, 0 if 12 hour time
  1706                                  .Map_call:
  1707 00000012 ????                    		RESW	1	; Address of case mapping call (DWORD)
  1708 00000014 ????                                    RESW	1       ; THIS IS TWO WORDS SO IT CAN BE INITIALIZED
  1709                                  				;  in pieces.

  1769                                  ; IOCTL.INC - MSDOS 6.0 - 1991
  1770                                  ;============================================================================
  1771                                  ; 09/07/2018 - Retro DOS v3.0
  1772                                  
  1773                                  ;*** J.K.
  1774                                  ;General Guide -
  1775                                  ;Category Code:
  1776                                  ; 0... .... DOS Defined
  1777                                  ; 1... .... User defined
  1778                                  ; .xxx xxxx Code
  1779                                  
  1780                                  ;Function Code:
  1781                                  ; 0... .... Return error if unsupported
  1782                                  ; 1... .... Ignore if unsupported
  1783                                  ; .0.. .... Intercepted by DOS
  1784                                  ; .1.. .... Passed to driver
  1785                                  ; ..0. .... Sends data/commands to device
  1786                                  ; ..1. .... Quries data/info from device
  1787                                  ; ...x .... Subfunction
  1788                                  ;
  1789                                  ; Note that "Sends/queries" data bit is intended only to regularize the
  1790                                  ; function set.  It plays no critical role; some functions may contain both
  1791                                  ; command and query elements. The convention is that such commands are
  1792                                  ; defined as "sends data".
  1793                                  
  1794                                  ;*****************************;*
  1795                                  ; BLOCK DRIVERS 	      ;*
  1796                                  ;*****************************;*
  1797

  1898                                  ; DEVSYM.INC
  1899                                  ;============================================================================
  1900                                  ; 07/07/2018 - Retro DOS v3.0
  1901                                  ; 30/04/2019 - Retro DOS v4.0 (DEVSYM.INC, MSDOS 6.0, 1991)
  1902                                  
  1903                                  ;**	DevSym.inc - Device Symbols
  1904                                  
  1905                                  ; The device table list has the form:
  1906                                  struc	SYSDEV
  1907 00000000 ????????                .NEXT:		resd 1		;Pointer to next device header
  1908 00000004 ????                    .ATT:		resw 1		;Attributes of the device
  1909 00000006 ????                    .STRAT:		resw 1		;Strategy entry point
  1910 00000008 ????                    .INT:		resw 1		;Interrupt entry point
  1911 0000000A ????????????????        .NAME:		resb 8		;Name of device (only first byte used for block)
  1912                                  .size:
  1913                                  endstruc
  1914                                  
  1915                                  ;
  1916                                  ; ATTRIBUTE BIT MASKS
  1917                                  ;
  1918                                  ; CHARACTER DEVICES:
  1919                                  ;
  1920                                  ; BIT 15 -> MUST BE 1
  1921                                  ;     14 -> 1 IF THE DEVICE UNDERSTANDS IOCTL CONTROL STRINGS
  1922                                  ;     13 -> 1 IF THE DEVICE SUPPORTS OUTPUT-UNTIL-BUSY
  1923                                  ;     12 -> UNUSED
  1924                                  ;     11 -> 1 IF THE DEVICE UNDERSTANDS OPEN/CLOSE
  1925                                  ;     10 -> MUST BE 0
  1926                                  ;      9 -> MUST BE 0
  1927                                  ;      8 -> UNUSED
  1928                                  ;      7 -> UNUSED
  1929                                  ;      6 -> UNUSED
  1930                                  ;      5 -> UNUSED
  1931                                  ;      4 -> 1 IF DEVICE IS RECIPIENT OF INT 29H
  1932                                  ;      3 -> 1 IF DEVICE IS CLOCK DEVICE
  1933                                  ;      2 -> 1 IF DEVICE IS NULL DEVICE
  1934                                  ;      1 -> 1 IF DEVICE IS CONSOLE OUTPUT
  1935                                  ;      0 -> 1 IF DEVICE IS CONSOLE INPUT
  1936                                  ;
  1937                                  ; BLOCK DEVICES:
  1938                                  ;
  1939                                  ; BIT 15 -> MUST BE 0
  1940                                  ;     14 -> 1 IF THE DEVICE UNDERSTANDS IOCTL CONTROL STRINGS
  1941                                  ;     13 -> 1 IF THE DEVICE DETERMINES MEDIA BY EXAMINING THE FAT ID BYTE.
  1942                                  ;	    THIS REQUIRES THE FIRST SECTOR OF THE FAT TO *ALWAYS* RESIDE IN
  1943                                  ;	    THE SAME PLACE.
  1944                                  ;     12 -> UNUSED
  1945                                  ;     11 -> 1 IF THE DEVICE UNDERSTANDS OPEN/CLOSE/REMOVABLE MEDIA
  1946                                  ;     10 -> MUST BE 0
  1947                                  ;      9 -> MUST BE 0
  1948                                  ;      8 -> UNUSED
  1949                                  ;      7 -> UNUSED
  1950                                  ;      6 -> IF DEVICE HAS SUPPORT FOR GETMAP/SETMAP OF LOGICAL DRIVES.
  1951                                  ;	    IF THE DEVICE UNDERSTANDS GENERIC IOCTL FUNCTION CALLS.
  1952                                  ;      5 -> UNUSED
  1953                                  ;      4 -> UNUSED
  1954                                  ;      3 -> UNUSED
  1955                                  ;      2 -> UNUSED
  1956                                  ;      1 -> UNUSED
  1957                                  ;      0 -> UNUSED
  1958                                  ;
  1959                                  
  1960                                  ;Attribute bit masks
  1961                                  DEVTYP	EQU     8000H           ;Bit 15 - 1 if Char, 0 if block
  1962                                  DEVIOCTL EQU    4000H           ;Bit 14 - CONTROL mode bit
  1963                                  ISFATBYDEV EQU  2000H           ;Bit 13 - Device uses FAT ID bytes, comp media.
  1964                                  
  1965                                  ; 09/07/2018 - Retro DOS (DEVSYM.INC, MSDOS 3.3, 1987) 
  1966                                  
  1967                                  OUTTILBUSY EQU	2000H		; OUTPUT UNTIL BUSY IS ENABLED
  1968                                  ISNET	   EQU	1000H		; BIT 12 - 1 IF A NET DEVICE, 0 IF
  1969                                  				;  NOT.  CURRENTLY BLOCK ONLY.
  1970                                  DEVOPCL    EQU	0800H		; BIT 11 - 1 IF THIS DEVICE HAS
  1971                                  				;  OPEN,CLOSE AND REMOVABLE MEDIA
  1972                                  				;  ENTRY POINTS, 0 IF NOT
  1973                                  
  1974                                  EXTENTBIT  EQU	0400H		; BIT 10 - CURRENTLY 0 ON ALL DEVS
  1975                                  				;  THIS BIT IS RESERVED FOR FUTURE USE
  1976                                  				;  TO EXTEND THE DEVICE HEADER BEYOND
  1977                                  				;  ITS CURRENT FORM.
  1978                                  
  1979                                  ; NOTE BIT 9 IS CURRENTLY USED ON IBM SYSTEMS TO INDICATE "DRIVE IS SHARED".
  1980                                  ;    SEE IOCTL FUNCTION 9. THIS USE IS NOT DOCUMENTED, IT IS USED BY SOME
  1981                                  ;    OF THE UTILITIES WHICH ARE SUPPOSED TO FAIL ON SHARED DRIVES ON SERVER
  1982                                  ;    MACHINES (FORMAT,CHKDSK,RECOVER,..).
  1983                                  
  1984                                  IOQUERY	EQU	0080H		;Bit 7 - Supports generic IOCtl query
  1985                                  
  1986                                  DEV320	EQU	0040H		;BIT 6 - FOR BLOCK DEVICES, THIS
  1987                                  				;DEVICE SUPPORTS SET/GET MAP OF
  1988                                  				;LOGICAL DRIVES, AND SUPPORTS
  1989                                  				;GENERIC IOCTL CALLS.
  1990                                  				;FOR CHARACTER DEVICES, THIS
  1991                                  				;DEVICE SUPPORTS GENERIC IOCTL.
  1992                                  				;THIS IS A DOS 3.2 DEVICE DRIVER.
  1993                                  
  1994                                  ISSPEC	EQU     0010H		;Bit 4 - This device is special ; 15/03/2018
  1995                                  ;ISIBM	EQU     0010H		;Bit 4 - This device is special
  1996                                  ISCLOCK EQU     0008H           ;Bit 3 - This device is the clock device.
  1997                                  ISNULL  EQU     0004H           ;Bit 2 - This device is the null device.
  1998                                  ISCOUT  EQU     0002H           ;Bit 1 - This device is the console output.
  1999                                  ISCIN   EQU     0001H           ;Bit 0 - This device is the console input.
  2000                                  
  2001                                  EXTDRVR	EQU	0002h		;BIT 1 - BLOCK DEVICE EXTENDED DRIVER
  2002                                  				; (MSDOS 6.0, DEVSYM.INC, 1991) ; 30/04/2019
  2003                                  
  2004                                  ;Static Reguest Header
  2005                                  struc	SRHEAD
  2006 00000000 ??                      .REQLEN:	resb 1		;Length in bytes of request block
  2007 00000001 ??                      .REQUNIT:	resb 1		;Device unit number
  2008 00000002 ??                      .REQFUNC:	resb 1		;Type of request
  2009 00000003 ????                    .REQSTAT:	resw 1		;Status Word
  2010 00000005 ????????????????                	resb 8		;Reserved for queue links
  2011                                  .size:
  2012                                  endstruc
  2013

  2016                                  STBUI   EQU     0200H           ;Bit 9 - Buisy
  2017                                  STDON   EQU     0100H           ;Bit 8 - Done
  2018                                  STECODE EQU     00FFH           ;Error code
  2019                                  WRECODE EQU     0
  2020                                  
  2021                                  ;Function codes
  2022                                  DINITHL EQU     26              ;Size of init header
  2023                                  DMEDHL  EQU     15              ;Size of media check header
  2024                                  DBPBHL  EQU     22              ;Size of Get BPB header
  2025                                  DRDWRHL EQU     22              ;Size of RD/WR header
  2026                                  DRDNDHL EQU     14              ;Size of non destructive read header
  2027                                  DSTATHL EQU     13              ;Size of status header
  2028                                  DFLSHL  EQU     15              ;Size of flush header
  2029                                  
  2030                                  DEVINIT EQU     0               ;Initialization
  2031                                  DEVMDCH EQU     1               ;Media check
  2032                                  DEVBPB  EQU     2               ;Get BPB
  2033                                  DEVRDIOCTL EQU  3               ;IOCTL read
  2034                                  DEVRD   EQU     4               ;Read
  2035                                  DEVRDND EQU     5               ;Non destructive read no wait (character devs)
  2036                                  DEVIST  EQU     6               ;Input status
  2037                                  DEVIFL  EQU     7               ;Input flush
  2038                                  DEVWRT  EQU     8               ;Write
  2039                                  DEVWRTV EQU     9               ;Write with verify
  2040                                  DEVOST  EQU     10              ;Output status
  2041                                  DEVOFL  EQU     11              ;Output flush
  2042                                  DEVWRIOCTL EQU  12              ;IOCTL write
  2043                                  
  2044                                  ; 09/07/2018 - Retro DOS v3.0 (DEVSYM.INC, MSDOS 3.3, 1987)

  2046                                  DEVCLS	EQU	14		;DEVICE CLOSE

  2049                                  ; 07/08/2018 - Retro DOS v3.0
  2050                                  REMHL	EQU	13		;SIZE OF REMOVABLE MEDIA HEADER
  2051                                  GENIOCTL EQU	19
  2052                                  
  2053                                  ; THE NEXT THREE ARE USED IN DOS 4.0
  2054                                  ;		     20
  2055                                  ;		     21
  2056                                  ;		     22
  2057

  2059                                  DEVSETOWN      EQU   24		;SET DEVICE OWNER
  2060                                  ; 18/05/2019 - Retro DOS v4.0

  2064

  2066                                  DEVOUTL        EQU   DEVWRT	; LENGTH OF OUTPUT UNTIL BUSY
  2067
